admreg: East Asia and Pacific,East Asia and Pacific

abstracts.cdata!:
The project outcome is satisfactory,
            sustainability is likely, and the institutional development
            impact is substantial. Lessons drawn from the project
            suggest that sustained road management should be supported
            within adequate technical assistance, including training,
            and advisory services, as well as performance monitoring, to
            provide effective implementation. Likewise, sustainable
            financing mechanisms should be in place to ensure adequate
            funding for road preservation, hence, disbursement of funds
            warrants special attention. However, technical assistance by
            itself, has a limited impact on local capacity building,
            unless it is accompanied by proper civil service reforms;
            thus, the role of monitoring, and the linkage between
            performance, and access to central allocations of resources,
            is crucial to establishing the importance of strong local
            capacity. Furthermore, much of the slow improvements in
            network conditions, and inadequacy of funding are related to
            prevailing poor construction quality, and inappropriate
            technology, which require credit access for: improved
            equipment; multi-year contracts for pavement works to
            encourage larger contractors at lower work-prices; and,
            appropriate alternative construction technologies. Though
            planning, programming, and monitoring practices proved
            sound, independent management, and performance monitoring
            should continue under the new decentralization process.
